top_comment.text:
As always, Petrolicious delivers a phenomenal video. If I could be as bold 
as to offer a tidbit of constructive criticism however: The scenery you 
guys film in is gorgeous, but in features past you've filmed videos in 
other geographic locations. It would be awesome if a degree of variety 
could be applied, just for the sake of experiencing a change of pace. Not 
saying the mountains surrounding LA aren't stunning, but you can't eat 
chocolate cake every day you know ;) Anyway, again, amazing work you guys, 
keep it coming! ﻿

comments.author: Anthony Pagano

comments.text:
Thanks. Toyota offered optional 13 inch Enkei wheels which luckily are the 
exact same offset and width as the Toyo Kogyo wheels on this car. Because 
of the lug design, I had to refit new, longer, stronger studs. Then I 
machined the RX7 center caps and found 1960s NOS old school Toyota center 
wheel emblems which luckily fit perfectly. I wanted it to look as similar 
to the period optional wheels as possible. The wheel wells were designed 
for larger tires and wheels for better handling and top speed. They really 
wanted to be competitive in the first run 24 hours Fuji endurance race. 
they placed 3rd and 4th behind 2 Toyota 2000GTs.
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

top_comment.author: R Adussar

comments.text:
Good catch. Its a 1960's Mitsubishi AR-300. Toyotas did not come standard 
with radios, so they had to be dealer installed. In the USA, Toyota offered 
Fujitsu Ten SS-90 radios and radio mounting kits and also antenna kits.The 
Mitsubishi in this car was in it when I bought it and has the Toyota 
antenna with the speaker kit. The radios are small in overall size and the 
volume control and on/off switches are on the right side to work best with 
right hand drive cars.

comments.text:
+Scott Sylvester I thought you said it correctly in the video. You say the 
entire engine is aluminum except for the cylinders(which if a person

comments.author: 05gtdriver

comments.text: +Scott Sylvester Oops, The cylinder heads are also aluminum.
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

comments.text:
+Jacob Kon Sorry, That incomplete and innacurate statement is one of the 
unfortunate edits that chopped of a few words that would have mattered. I 
meant to point out that the engine block is aluminum except the barrels and 
cylinder heads. The transmission case and differential carrier are also 
aluminum. The hood, trunk lid, rood and seats are also aluminum. the body 
is made from purposely thin steel
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

comments.text:
+MechRider89
(it's aluminum except the cylinder heads)
comments.author: Jacob Kon

comments.text:
+Scott Sylvester
Having a bit of previous experience with Volkswagen and Corvairs, a fellow 
brought me a Toyota Publica a few years back and I found the little opposed 
air-cooled two cylinder engine really easy to work on. It needed new 
pistons and all the overhaul parts were supplied by the local Toyota dealer 
in Toronto, no problem. The fan being attached to the end of the crank, 
like a Type II Volks, kept the cooling constant without belt problems and 
the engine mounted between the front suspension onto a regular inline 
transmission, with drive to the rear.

After the rebuild, it was still underpowered by our standards, but still a 
very interesting view of what had helped build the Toyota brand in Japan. I 
can see that the upgrades they performed on your sports model really got it 
into the fun range! Congratulations on preserving a very unique model and I 
was glad to finally see one in action and make the comparison to my own 
experiences.
comments.author: MonzaSSguy

comments.text:
+Scott Sylvester Thank's so much for sharing this with petrolicious for 
everyone to enjoy. I never even knew the sports 800 existed until just now, 
such a fabulous looking car my friend. Thanks for giving the Japanese Iron 
some love.
comments.author: MechRider89

comments.text:
+seolforag47 I can understand that you might think its over restored but 
consider this: The steering wheel dash, top cover of dash, gauges and 
switches are all original to the car untouched. All glass, stainless 
original. even the windshield rubber is original. The seats have all 
original foam with matched material to the original red which was too 
ripped to sit on. The rubber floor mats are factory Toyota. The door panels 
and all vinyl is original except for the area behind the seats. The paint 
is much better than the original single stage enamel, but the doors, hood, 
truck and roof were not altered to fit, and the gaps on the hood are 
purposely kept original.I did the sanding masking and a shop friend did the 
rest. The aluminum panels still show the hammer marks underneath with no 
repair. I was lucky to start with a straight rust free car. Most of the 
work was on a complete mechanical rebuild.. I don't think you would say its 
ridiculously over restored if you saw in in person. The camera filters 
results are amazing. The owner is mostly unrestored as you can see with no 
filtering. But thanks, it is one of the nicest cars I have ever owned.
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

comments.text:
+seolforag47 It's only over-restored if he has any designs on selling it. 
If it's meant to be a keeper then there's no such thing as over-restoration.
comments.author: OldcarsNmusic

comments.text:
Nice to see something different even quirky on here from time to time but 
ridiculously way over restored. Wouldn't have even come out of the factory 
like that.
comments.author: seolforag47

comments.text: +Scott Sylvester Beautiful car thanks for sharing it ...

comments.author: xynudu

comments.text:
+xynudu All Sports 800s came with silver painted 12 inch wheels and hub 
caps specific to the S800. I still have all five original ones which look 
too skinny and small. Toyota claims the top speed with the long gears was 
100mph. On that video I had an indicated 85 mph 3 times without any 
problem.  Once before I restored it I had it to 95 which was a bit frantic. 
It's actually is very impressive at high speed aerodynamically, but not 
much fun on any tight corner over 70 like a modern car.
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

comments.text:
Interesting.  The wheels look good. What wheels did it have on it when you 
purchased it?  What is the maximum speed of the car approximately ? Rob
comments.author: xynudu

comments.text:
The original optional wheels offered by Toyota for racing etc were Enkei 
wheels. Those are very rare and big $$. The wheels you see are indeed the 
first year Mazda RX7Toyo Kogyo wheels that happen to be similar to the 
original Enkei wheels. They are the same 13 inch, same offset and same bolt 
pattern! I found a set of new, but old Toyota center caps from the sixties 
and machined them into the center of the Mazda wheels.
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

comments.text:
+Scott Sylvester
When I looked at it I thought the alloy wheels looked very much like early

comments.text:
Hi Thanks. It was built Sept 1966 as a 1967 model. Yes I love the Hondas 
too. I have had both cars. The honda has much less torque down low until 
you wind it up just like a period 4 cyl Honda MC. It sounds great too! The 
torque curve on the boxer Toyota is much flatter with good HP over a wider 
range. It sounds growly like a BMW MC. The Toyota won the first ever 24 
hour Fuji endurance race and many more after that besting the Hondas whose 
aerodynamic design could not reach the top speed or get the fuel mileage at 
close to 100mph as needed. Weighed less too. Both great period cars. I will 
tell you that the Toyota engine is much much simpler and easier to keep 
running right and to rebuild it. It was a lesson in a flat engine sitting 
low under a low hood making it slippery in the wind. Scott
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

top_comment.text:
Toyota is a boring car maker... but only in North America. In Japan they 
are making very exciting and high tech cars that aren`t sold anywhere else 
besides Japan. Like the rear wheel drive Mark X which is a BMW 3 series 
beater. Not the mention the Toyota Crown when is like the most luxurious 
car I`ve ever sat in. The amount of tech in there is just amazing. Even in 
the old days when they made a sedan called an Aristo. Which is the Lexus GS 
in the US but in Japan it came with a Supra twin turbo 2JZ engine. The 
japanese Legends like the Mark 2, chaser jxz series and the Ae86 were 
fantastic cars. I currently drives a JDM Toyota Celsior which is called the 
Lexus LS400 here. On the outside they both look pretty much the same but 
underneath and the suspension set up is completely different from the USDM 
Lexus, plus it`s got the 1UZ FE V8 engine which is pretty much the best V8 
of all time. (I`ll take no arguments) The only problem is that they were 
only sold in japan and not a lot of people in north america knows about 
them. Here we only get shitty camrys and corollas that were designed for 
the North American Market. I guess the japanese just don`t think that the 
rest of the world deserves their best products.   ﻿
top_comment.author: TEDBOSS100

comments.text:
I was in Japan in the 80's and was struck by how many of the cars like 
Coronas and Datsun 510s etc all had full instrumentation, wood like sport 
steering wheels, and dual carbs. The later Mustang-like Celicas had 
fantastic looking chrome bumpers rather than our ugly USA rubber safety 
stuff. Even the teeney 2 cylinder Honda Z360s had dual carbs! This Sports 
800 is an example of what they had over there.
comments.author: Scott Sylvester

captions.text:
- I used to wash cars and I worked
at gas stations, so when I could afford

it, when I was 15, it was a 1959 Fiat 600
suicide doors and for $110, it just made

me happy. It might have well have been a
Porsche, and it started from there and why
I didn't get off of that, I don't know.

My name is Scott Sylvester and
I'm driving a 1967 Toyota Sports 800.

Not many people much at all about these
because they
were only made for the Japanese market.

And so in this case, the
total production was 3,131 over the four

years they made them and only about 300 or
less were in the left hand drive.

Coming out of the war, Japan was actually
making most of their cars under license to

other manufacturers. They didn't have
their own ideas and it was when the

Japanese ministries decided we really
should build for our own needs because

they had so a bad gas crisis, and their
roads were all small.

These were the first of the fun sports
cars for the Japanese public.

They chose the engine itself was already
had been produced for the public and

believe it or not, it was also used in
certain buses in Tokyo. By choosing the

Publica they then went to work by
stripping it down and putting different
